title-group.article-title: Identification of the most significant comfort factors for textiles from processing mechanical, handfeel, fabric construction, and perceived tactile comfort data

article-meta.aff: 2U.S. Army Natick Soldier R, D and E Center, USA

author-notes.corresp: Les Sztandera, Philadelphia University, 4201 Henry Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19144, USA Email: SztanderaL@philau.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Engineered fabrics are desired for military protective clothing applications. Such fabrics, exhibiting high tactile comfort, can be computationally designed. Through the use of an extensive database that contains handfeel, mechanical, construction, and tactile comfort data for fabrics, desired comfort can be predicted by measuring a limited number of properties. Output systems can be optimized to exhibit the highest level of comfort by engineering a fabric with specific properties.

Using an extensive fabric database, we identify the most significant handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties influencing tactile fabric comfort. This is done through the use of regression analysis of handfeel, mechanical, construction fabric properties, and perceived tactile comfort, using B un-standardized coefficients and Beta standardized coefficients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The most basic and pervasively used materials by the United States Department of Defense are the fabrics in combat uniforms. They provide essential protection characteristics and are frequently the only barrier between the elements and the soldier. The ability to engineer this protective clothing system, beginning with the basic fabric, is the first step in the systems engineering approach for the overall ‘Soldier System.’

The tactile and thermal comfort of fabric, which is closely linked to user acceptability, has been recently studied and relationships between clothing comfort and cognitive performance have been identified. Material selection is critical to ensure the least interference with the soldiers’ ability to perform physical or cognitive tasks.1 While fit is often an important factor contributing to user acceptability of the combat uniform, tactile and appearance factors are equivalently important to functional factors, such as protection and durability.2 Environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity, which vary widely by location, have significant impact on the comfort, satisfaction, and user acceptability of combat fabrics. In warm conditions, tactile discomfort increases with humidity and may be due to friction between skin and clothing. When fabrics, ranging from rough burlap to wool, cotton, polyester, and smooth silk, are pulled across the skin, the measured pull force increases with humidity and perspiration, as does the fabric’s perceived texture or roughness.3

The gold standard for predicting the comfort of garments is through controlled wear trials. However, with hundreds of fabrics to examine, such studies are prohibitive in terms of time and cost unless an effective method for down selection is used. The present study examines the extent to which handfeel, mechanical, construction, and perceived comfort data can be used to predict the comfort of fabrics for possible use in future wear trials.

A number of methods for sensory and instrumental characterization of the handfeel properties of fabrics are available, including the Handfeel Spectrum Descriptive Analysis (HSDA) method4 and the Kawabata Evaluation System. In addition, a number of methods exist for evaluating the handfeel comfort of fabrics, including the Comfort Affective Labeled Magnitude (CALM) scale, developed specifically for use on fabrics and which has been demonstrated to have a high degree of sensitivity to fabric differences, good construct validity, and high test-retest reliability.5 These methods have established a basis for a standardized approach to characterizing the tactile properties of clothing fabrics and analyzing the contributions of their sensory and mechanical properties to perceived comfort.

In this study the above methods are used to investigate and determine the most important fabric properties that influence tactile comfort. Ultimately, what is envisaged, in addition to assessing the comfort properties of existing fabrics, are new quantifiable methods and models to engineer and design future fabrics to provide prescribed and optimum tactile comfort for a given scenario and environment.

sec.title: Predicting comfort from sensory, instrumental and construction properties
sec.p: Numerous previous attempts have been made to correlate fabric properties with perceived comfort. Models based on energy equations,6 finite element analysis,7,8 stochastic formulations9 and Artificial Neural Networks10 exist to identify the interrelationship between the structure of textile materials and their comfort related functional properties. Researchers have found that human tactile perception of a textile material is complex. Sensory or tactile comfort, identified by hand touch, is a result of how much stress is generated in the material and how it is distributed over the skin. It has, consequently, a strong relationship with the handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties of the fabric.11 The handfeel and sensory comfort properties of fabrics have been studied for many years, but it was not until the 1990s that standardized techniques of sensory descriptive analysis and psychophysics were applied to obtaining these measures.2,5,12–15

When relating fabric, construction or handfeel properties to perceived tactile comfort, early work focused primarily on identifying one-to-one relationships between variables using correlations or simple linear regression.16,17 However, more recent research has focused on the use of multiple regression and artificial intelligence analysis in order to predict comfort.18–22 Many different methods have been used to build such models for the prediction of tactile comfort.23–28 Analyzing the relationship between instrumentally-determined characteristics of fabrics in the context of predicting tactile perception has been researched because of the increased application of sophisticated fabrics for functional clothing systems. Engineered fabrics are being used increasingly in commercial and domain-specific systems. Such fabrics with specified desirable consumer characteristics can be computationally designed.

This research examines mechanical properties, measured by the Kawabata Evaluation System for Fabrics (KES-F), and handfeel properties, measured by a trained sensory panel, as well as construction data provided by laboratory measurements, and presents statistical methodologies using B un-standardized and Beta standardized coefficients for combining and mapping them to the perceived tactile comfort of fabrics with the purpose of identifying the most significant properties. A database of 48 fabrics is examined to analyze and map the relations.

sec.title: Mechanical measurements
sec.p:
A diversified database of 48 fabrics, including woven, knitted, and nonwoven materials, was selected for evaluation. Laminated fabrics with water, fire, and chemical retardant finishes were included. The fabrics’ mechanical properties were measured using the KES-FB Kawabata Evaluation System. The definitions of each term appear in Table 1. Table 1.
Definitions of mechanical properties
Parameters Description
Tensile
LT Linearity of load/extension curve (stress, strain relationship at tensile loading conditions)
WT Tensile energy (energy consumed by the material to strain it to a particular limit)
RT Tensile resilience (energy absorbed by the material when deformed elastically)
EMT Extensibility (ability of material to be stretched without breaking)
Bending
B Bending rigidity (material resistance to bending)
2HB Hysteresis of bending moment (energy dissipated by the material at time of bending)
Shearing
G Shear stiffness (resistance to deformation at shear loading)
2HG Hysteresis of shear force at 0.5 degrees (energy dissipated by the material at time of shear loading)
2HG5 Hysteresis of shear force at 5 degrees
Compression
LC Linearity of compression/thickness curve (stress, strain relationship at compression loading conditions)
WC Compressional energy (energy consumed by the material) to strain it to a particular limit)
RC Compressional resilience (energy absorbed by the material when deformed elastically)
Surface
MIU Coefficient of friction (resistance to sliding of two surfaces in contact)
MMD Mean deviation of coefficient of friction (frictional roughness of the surface)
SMD Geometric roughness (geometrical roughness of the material)
Construction
T Fabric thickness
W Fabric weight/unit area

KES-FB testing was performed under standard textile testing conditions of 21°C and 65% relative humidity. The KES requires a 20 cm by 20 cm square specimen. Five replicate specimens were prepared from each fabric. Each test specimen was subjected to KES testing following the prescribed order: bending, surface, compression, shear, and tensile. Data were collected for both the warp and weft direction for each test specimen, except compression for which there is no direction. The mean KES property values for warp and weft for all five specimens were calculated.

Mass per unit area is reported in ounces per square yard following the instructions in ASTM D3776-07, Standard Test Method for Mass Per Unit Area (Weight) of Fabric. Five samples were die cut from each fabric using a JA King Model PSC-AC pneumatic die cutter. Each die cut sample had an area of 5.7 inches square, totaling the required 20 square inches specified in the methodology. Each sample was individually weighed on a Sauter AR1014 top-loading electronic balance. The balance is connected to an ILE-90 Textile Testing Processor (multi-scale), which automatically calculated the ounces per square yard from the gram weight of the specimen on the balance. By multiplying the average ounces per square yard weight by 3.39, the weight was converted to milligrams per square centimeter, which is the mass unit used in the KES system.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: The same set of 48 fabrics as were tested for mechanical properties were evaluated by a trained handfeel panel.2

sec.title: Panel
sec.p: The evaluation of the handfeel attributes was done by an existing Spectrum skinfeel attribute panel consisting of 11 members. Panelists received approximately 12 hours of training on the protocol used in testing and participated in an additional 36 hours of practice before evaluations began.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p:
The tactile attributes evaluated are shown in the left hand column of Table 2. The samples were evaluated in duplicate using an established protocol. A 0–100 point intensity scale was used with 0 = none, 50 = moderate and 100 = very strong. Data were converted to a 15-pt scale using a linear transformation in order to align the absolute values with those used in previous research.5 Each fabric was presented to panelists in a manila folder to protect the fabric. All testing was conducted on the side of the fabric that touches the skin. In order to assess the sensitivity of the methods/panel, one-way ANOVAs were conducted across samples for each attribute. A high level of statistical discrimination across the sample set was observed for each attribute at the 95% confidence level. Table 2.
Definitions of handfeel properties and range of observed ratings across fabrics
Property Lower boundary Upper boundary
Grainy – amount of small, round particles in the surface of the sample 2.27 12.28
Gritty – amount of small, abrasive, picky particles in the surface of the sample 4.45 12.47
Fuzzy (circular motion) – amount of pile, fiber, fuzz on the surface of the sample 1.83 9.80
Thickness – perceived distance between the thumb and the index finger (when the sample is placed between the two) 2.75 14.41
Tensile stretch – degree to which the sample stretches from its original shape 0.68 14.49
Hand friction – force required to move the palm of the hand across the surface of the sample 4.28 12.04
Fabric to fabric friction – force required to move the fabric over itself 4.11 13.04
Depression depth – amount that the sample depresses when downward force is applied 1.56 12.15
Springiness – rate at which the sample returns to its original position after the downward force is released 1.39 9.01
Force to gather – amount of force required to gather the sample into the palm 1.78 14.78
Force to compress – amount of force required to compress the gathered sample into the palm 1.68 14.20
Fullness/volume – amount of material felt in the hand 2.32 15.17
Stiffness – degree to which the sample feels pointed, ridged, and cracked; not pliable 1.59 14.49
Compression resilience – perceived force with which the sample exerts resistive pressure against the cupped hands 1.63 13.43
Compression resilience rate – rate at which the sample returns to its original shape or rate at which the sample opens after compression 1.56 13.64
Noise intensity – loudness of the noise 1.48 13.20
Noise pitch – pitch (frequency) of the noise 2.52 13.28

sec.title: Fabric construction measures
sec.p:
All 48 samples were also evaluated for construction properties. Six construction parameters, measured in a laboratory, were also selected as possible inputs (fabric structure was assigned a number and was treated as a numeric value in addition to the five numeric parameters listed below, but was not included as an input in regression analysis). All construction properties and their ranges are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Construction properties
Property Description Minimum value Maximum value
Wfc Weight (oz./sq.yd) 1 20
EPI Warp EPI (ends per inch) 0 200
WETx Warp equivalent tex# 0 200
PPI Fill PPI (picks per inch) 0 90
FETx Fill PPI (picks per inch) 0 300
FS Fabric structure N/A N/A

Fabric samples were conditioned at 21°C and 65% relative humidity prior to all construction determinations. Fabric count is reported as the number of yarns per inch. ASTM D3775-03a, Standard Test Method for Warp End Count and Filling Pick Count of Woven Fabric was followed to determine the number of ends and picks per inch of all woven fabrics. The test method in section 12 of ASTM D3887-96 (2004), Standard Specification for Tolerances for Knitted Fabric, was employed to determine the number of wales and courses per inch of all knit fabrics.

The number of warp ends per inch and filling picks per inch were determined by counting the number of yarns using an Electro-Optix, Inc. 5X Linen Tester LT-5 Pick Glass. Five determinations were taken from random areas of two or more fabric samples. The number of wales and courses per inch were determined in the same manner. During the fabric count, observations were made to determine whether yarns were single or ply construction. The single or ply construction was included in the yarn number designation.

ASTM D1059-01 Standard Test Method for Yarn Number Based on Short-Length Specimens was used to determine yarn size. Because the tex system is recognized as the world standard, an additional column converts all yarn numbers to tex for an immediate size comparison. Tex conversion of all yarn numbers reported was performed following ASTM D2260-03 Standard Tables of Conversion Factors and Equivalent Yarn Numbers Measured in Various Numbering Systems. Minimum value of 0 (tex/picks per inch) was used as the lower end of the scale as a reference point. For picks per inch, it means that there are no horizontal yarns in a fabric (nonwoven fabrics or laminate fabrics). The number increases as the yarn size goes down if you have a woven fabric. This number is little different for knit fabrics as it is counting something different. For tex, it means the size of the yarn. Because the yarn can be infinitely small depending on its use, the lowest number approaches 0, without quite reaching it. Depending on the fiber content, the yarn number is converted from one system to another.
Identification of the yarn spinning system was determined through visual and microscopic examination. Twist behavior of the yarn was also used.

sec.title: Samples
sec.p: The same set of 48 fabrics was evaluated by 50 consumer panelists for perceived tactile comfort.

sec.title: Panelists
sec.p: Consumer panelists were recruited from a university faculty, staff and students, via a Request for Participation email sent globally to the university community. University approval to conduct the study was obtained from the University’s Institutional Review Board. All participants provided consent prior to participation. They were tested in groups that started at the same time, with the start of testing every 90 minutes during a 3-hour block of testing.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Upon arrival, participants were assigned to specific seats in the testing room, with the provision that no two participants sit close enough to allow for possible sharing of information. Participants washed their hands with a hand sanitizer prior to testing. Fabric samples were delivered in humidity-controlled containers to the testing room. Each fabric sample was marked with its three-digit code for identification. Samples were placed individually in manila testing folders that were also marked with the three-digit identification code. The order of presentation was determined in advance and was detailed on the random sequence protocol sheet. Upon completion of all sessions for a particular day, samples in their matching folders were placed back in the humidity-controlled container until the next testing session.

Participants handled the fabric as long as they liked. After feeling the fabric, they rated the perceived comfort on the CALM scale,5 shown in Figure 1. This scale, developed at the U.S. Army Natick Soldier Research Development and Engineering Center, Natick, MA5 ranges from −100 to 100, where a score of −100 represents the greatest imaginable discomfort, and a 100 represents the greatest imaginable comfort. The other labels are distributed in a manner that corresponds to the ratios of semantic meanings among the word/label descriptors as determined by a magnitude estimation procedure.5 The advantages of the CALM scale over other comfort scales commonly used in the literature include the fact that the comfort/discomfort experienced by an individual can be easily indexed by simply placing a mark somewhere on the line. By having positioned the phrases of comfort/discomfort along the analogue line scale at points representing the magnitude of their semantic meaning as determined by a magnitude estimation procedure, it becomes possible to treat the measured distances along the scale as ratio level data. This ratio nature of the scale enables statements to be made about whether a particular fabric or garment is 20%, 40%, three times, etc., as comfortable (or uncomfortable) as another one, something that cannot be said with other, simple line or category scales. Last, by using the ‘greatest imaginable’ comfort (or discomfort) as end-points on the scale, the scale enables better discrimination between samples/conditions that are either very high or very low in comfort/discomfort and establishes a common ruler by which comfort/discomfort ratings of different subjects can be compared.5 Figure 1.
Comfort Affective Labeled Magnitude (CALM) scale.
After rating each fabric, a proctor removed the folder holding the fabric, and provided the next testing folder. The procedure was repeated until the participant completed all trials.

sec.title: Ranges of mechanical, sensory and construction properties
sec.p:
In so far as the main focus of the study is the prediction of comfort from the various mechanical, sensory and construction parameters, the details of the mean values obtained for the 48 fabrics on each of the multiple parameters are not of direct importance. However, to give the reader a feel for the wide range of fabrics that were tested, Table 4 shows the range of mechanical values obtained across the 48 fabrics. Similarly, the right hand sides of Tables 2 and 3 show the ranges of obtained values for the sensory and construction parameters. Table 4.
Range of mechanical properties as measured using KES-FB Kawabata evaluation system
Property Description Minimum value Maximum value
EMT Elongation (%) 0.98 35.87
LT Linearity of load-extension curve (ND) 0.16 1.28
WT Tensile energy (gf.cm/cm2) 0.54 58.62
RT Tensile resilience (%) 22.46 63.26
B Bending rigidity (gf/cm.degree) 0.01 5.37
2HB Hysteresis of bending moment (gf. cm/cm) 0.01 6.98
G Shear rigidity (gf/cm. degree) 0.45 25.54
2HG Hysteresis of shear force at 0.5 degrees of shear angle (gf/cm) 0.74 172.51
2HG5 Hysteresis of shear force at 5 degrees of shear angle (gf/cm) 1.64 130.26
LC Linearity of compression- thickness curve (ND) 0.23 0.84
WC Compressional energy (gf.cm/cm2) 0.03 1.66
RC Compressional re silience (%) 37.11 102.57
MIU Coefficient of friction (ND) 014 0.44
MMD Mean deviation of MHJ (ND) 0.01 0.18
SMD Geometrical roughness (micron) 1.53 91.89
T Fabric thickness (cm) 0.02515 0.2388
W Fabric weight per unit area (mg/cm2) 4.10 64.88

sec.title: Regression analysis
sec.p: The 17 mechanical, 17 handfeel, and six construction variables were mapped to 2400 tactile comfort scores (48 × 50). Averages were selected to represent the 40 dimensional vectors and their corresponding tactile comfort scores.

Combined handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties data sets were used to form a regression equation with the 40 input properties as independent variables and the tactile comfort score as the dependent variable. The resulting equation (1) is given below. (1)Tactile Comfort Score=152.614-52.452Fabric_structure+15.898 Wt_Oz.sg.yd+0.05 5EPI -0.943Warp_Equiv._Tex#+1.178PPI+0.900Fill _ Euiva.Tex#-0.469 Gritty -2.231 Grainy-5.25 3 Fuzzy-17.867 Thickness+3.874Tensile Stretch +17.179Hand Friction-1 0.0 2 0Fab - to - Fab Friction -4.857Depression Depth-0.153Springiness+36.365Force to Gather -34.764Force to Compress+37.977Fullness-12.893Stiffness +19.0 38Compressional Resilience-29.21 0Compressional Resilience Rate +4.9 0 9Noise Intensity-4.0 54Noise Pitch+5.652EMT+55.221LT -2.7 0 3WT+0.719RT-9.913B+14.83 0HB-6.172G+1.326HG -0.748HG5+14.198LC+33.396WC-0.396RC-181.5 0 4MIU -375.974MMD-0.826SMD-329.268T-5.439W
The equation fits with an R2 value of 0.990 and an adjusted R2 is 0.920.

An adjusted R2 measures the proportion of the variation in the Tactile Comfort Score accounted for by the independent mechanical, handfeel, and construction variables. Unlike R2, it allows for the degrees of freedom associated with the sums of the squares. Therefore, even though the residual sum of squares decreases or remains the same, as new independent variables are added, the residual variance does not. For this reason, adjusted R2 is generally considered to be a more accurate goodness-of-fit measure than R2.

sec.title: Dimension reduction using stepwise regression analysis
sec.p: Combined handfeel, Kawabata mechanical, and construction properties include 40 independent attributes and one dependent attribute. Though all the independent attributes contribute in the regression equation to predict the tactile comfort score, few of the attributes contribute more than others. If the attributes that contribute the least to the prediction ability of the regression equation are eliminated, the overall dimension of the data set comes down. One of the mechanisms to reduce the dimension of the data is stepwise regression analysis.

Data containing the handfeel, Kawabata mechanical, construction properties, and the CALM comfort scores for 48 fabrics are used to formulate the set of stepwise (forward) regression equations with R2 increasing from 0.741 to 0.913 in the final equation. Out of the 40 parameters, six were included in the final equation (2), based on the parameters’ contribution to the overall variance of the data set.

The attributes were entered or removed in the steps of forward regression analysis based on the significance (probability) of the F value, which shows the significance level associated with adding the variable for that step. The stepwise criteria used was (probability of F to enter ≤ 0.05; probability of F to remove ≥0.1).
The resulting equation is as follows: (2)Tactile Comfort Score =136.130-5.252Grainy -4.555Gritty-9.434COM _ RR -162.129K _ MMD +1.987K _ W -4.248Wt _ oz.sq.yd

The equation fits with an R2 value of 0.924 and an adjusted R2 of 0.913. Note that COM_RR is Compression Resilience Rate and the variables starting with K_ indicate Kawabata (mechanical) properties. As K_W is fabric weight/unit area in mg/cm2 (in Kawabata system) and Wt is also weight but measured as a construction variable measured in oz/sq.yd. Both weights can be combined to produce a single weight variable W (the conversion is as follows: oz/sq.yd multiplied by 3.39 equals mg/cm2).
Based on the above, equation (2) can be re-written as: (3)Tactile Comfort Score =136.130-5.252Grainy -4.555Gritty-9.434COM _ RR -162.129K _ MMD-12.414W

Out of the 40 parameters, five (three handfeel, one mechanical, and one construction) were included in the final equation (3) based on their contribution to the overall variance of the data set. The above equations are in B un-standardized coefficients.

In order to validate the obtained model, five additional fabrics (approximately 10% of the overall set of 48) that were not used during the original testing (model establishment) were evaluated, and the predicted comfort scores paralleled the observed in terms of magnitude and direction (0.20 vs. 0.30; −11.38 vs. −12.30; 12.56 vs. 7.18; −3.38 vs. −8.32, and 15.08 vs. 9.88). A Pearson correlation coefficient calculated between the predicted and observed scores resulted in r = 0.978, indicating a high degree of prediction for the model. A more comprehensive validation of the model will be undertaken and reported once additional new fabrics are analyzed.

So far, we have examined the most significant handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties influencing tactile fabric comfort, and have identified them using B un-standardized coefficients. The initial 40 parameter set was reduced to sets of one to six properties. Adjusted R2 values increased to 0.913 reflecting a sound goodness-of-fit measure and providing reasonable means for identifying the mechanical, handfeel, and construction properties that influence tactile fabric comfort the most. Grainy, Gritty, Compression Resilience Rate, Mean Deviation of the Coefficient of Friction, and Weight (including K_W weight measured under Kawabata system) were found to be the most influential properties producing the highest R2 (0.924) and adjusted R2 (0.913) values as a set. The negative coefficient weightings, for handfeel variables (Grainy, Gritty, and Compression Resilience Rate), support data reported previously5 showing that tactile comfort is inversely related to the average perceived intensity of handfeel variables when all tactile attributes are judged using unidirectional rating scales that range from low to high values on the underlying tactile dimensions. In such cases, extremely low scores reflect the absence of sensory tactile feelings on the skin. Based on the current data, it could also be concluded that comfort decreases as Mean Deviation of the Coefficient of Friction, and Weight (Wt_oz.sq.yd) increase.

The above results can be compared to results obtained using the same Kawabata measures and the same sensory handfeel and comfort techniques as used in the present study, but applied to a different set of clothing fabrics. In this earlier research5 the Kawabata and handfeel variables were first reduced into factor scores to reduce the number of dimensions. However, the final multiple regression analyses to predict sensory tactile comfort of the fabrics from the factor scores revealed that the handfeel factor of ‘sensory surface texture/depth’, upon which the attributes of gritty, hand friction, and compression resilience rate were loaded, and the Kawabata factor of ‘surface texture’, upon which the mean deviation of the coefficient of friction and geometric roughness were loaded were of the most important factors predicting sensory handfeel comfort. As such, it is clear that many of the same sensory and Kawabata variables are driving handfeel comfort of the fabrics in both studies.

sec.title: Beta standardized coefficients analysis
sec.p: Next, we examined Beta coefficients which are the standardized regression coefficients calculated in the stepwise regression analysis. The absolute magnitudes of Beta coefficients reflect their relative importance in predicting comfort values.

Standardized coefficients (Beta) are the coefficients that were obtained by standardizing all of the variables in the regression, including the dependent and all of the independent variables, and running the regression. By standardizing the variables before running the regression, all of the variables were put on the same scale, thus allowing for comparison of the magnitude of the coefficients to see which one has more of an effect. Beta coefficients can be compared only within a model, not between models. Because the non-standardized coefficients (B) deal with raw (or ‘original’) values, they are used to construct the prediction equations from handfeel, mechanical, and construction parameters to perceived comfort values. All non-standardized (B) and standardized coefficients (Beta) are listed in Table 5. Table 5.
Un-standardized (B) and standardized coefficients (Beta) coefficients

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The research reported here provides an approach to the analysis of the contributions of handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties to the perceived tactile comfort of clothing fabrics. The approach is based on the use of instrumental measurements for mechanical and construction variables in conjunction with psychophysical methods for assessing both the qualitative and quantitative aspects of sensory handfeel and comfort experience. The approach of using human sensory judgments of handfeel properties and comfort distinguishes this work from many other studies in the literature that attempt to predict the handle and comfort of fabrics using only Kawabata mechanical measures and the formulae derived by Kawabata to predict handfeel and comfort properties of suit fabrics.29,30 The latter approaches are not truly predictive, in the sense of obtaining independent and dependent measures on a fabric and predicting the dependent variable from the independent variables. Rather, these approaches simply obtain Kawabata mechanical measures on test fabrics and algorithmically calculate ‘handfeel’ and ‘comfort’ values, with no independent verification by human respondents of the perceived handfeel or comfort of those fabrics.

The current approach also demonstrates the utility of a multidisciplinary approach in which mechanical and construction properties of fabrics obtained in a laboratory are combined with sensory descriptive evaluations of the same fabrics obtained from a trained sensory panel to predict the comfort response of consumers to those fabrics. This multidisciplinary approach to comfort prediction is uncommon in the literature, due to the diverse nature of the data acquisition requirements.

The present data also demonstrate that by reducing the high dimensionality (40) of handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties that can be measured for fabrics to a small number of variables (one to six), it is possible to derive regression models to predict the perceived comfort of the fabrics. Eventually these models may be used to engineer high comfort fabrics for military specific or commercial applications. The results of this research, as reported here, show that a combination of sensory and instrumental factors can be used to reliably predict tactile comfort of fabrics, if their measured handfeel, mechanical, and construction properties are within ranges of the universe of fabrics used for establishing the models.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the US Department of Defense (grant number W911QY-10-1-0002).

CardelloAVWinterhalterCSchutzHG. Predicting the handle and comfort of military clothing fabrics from sensory and instrumental data: development and application of new psychophysical methods. Textile Res J 2003; 73(3): 221–237.
